description: Music 075 401 (Dr. Ramsey): Exploration of the family of musical idioms called jazz. Attention will be given to issues of style, to selected musicians, and to the social, cultural, and scholarly issues raised by its study. Music 075 601 (Professor Parberry): Development of jazz from the beginning of the 20th Century to present. Analysis of the stylistic flux of jazz, such as the progression from dance music to bebop and the emergence of the avant-garde and jazz rock. Attention will be given to both the artists who generated the changes and the cultural conditions that often provided the impetus.
name: JAZZ:STYLE & HISTORY

values.comments:
This course examines the development of jazz from the beginning of the 20th Century to present. It analyzes the stylistic flux of jazz, such as the progression from dance music to bebop and the emergence of the avant-garde and jazz-rock. Attention is given to both the artists who generated the changes and the cultural and social conditions that often provided the impetus.

Students who have taken the course have reported that it was “fun” and “stimulated interest regardless of the students’ musical background.” The subject matter was described as “fascinating,” and students voiced their excitement over the musical performances throughout the semester, which they said set this class apart from other music history courses.

Professor Ramsey “went above and beyond” to engage his students and make the material understandable. Several students did note, however, that he was at times very self-promoting, requiring students to attend his performances and those of his friends. Overall, the opinion of Professor Ramsey was positive and students really appreciated his ability to demonstrate relevant musical terms by playing examples during the lecture. 

The course has a small workload, consisting mostly of “interesting readings,” and the exams were reported by most to be fairly easy. Students who have taken the course recommend it to “any student with even the slightest interest in jazz.”
